content: Does anyone remember this quote from the first Presidential Debate? quote: Barack Obama: You may end up getting a $5,000 tax credit. Here’s the only problem: Your employer now has to pay taxes on the health care that you’re getting from your employer. McCain’s plan doesn’t call for taxing employers on health care benefits; it would instead tax employees. As the law stands now, employees don’t pay taxes on the dollar value of their health insurance benefits. Under McCain’s plan, they would. This article was in the Washington Post today. quote: With President Obama's plan to tax the rich to pay for health care facing deep skepticism on Capitol Hill, key lawmakers are pressing a different way to raise money: taxing the health benefits workers receive from their employers. Since companies began offering group health insurance on a large scale during World War II, the value of that benefit has never been counted as income, reducing workers' taxable earnings by an average of $9,000 a year for family coverage. In recent weeks, however, Sen. Max Baucus (D-Mont.), chairman of the tax-writing Finance Committee, has repeatedly advocated changing tax laws to include employer benefits, arguing that it makes sense to fund the health-care changes by sucking cash out of the existing system. Meanwhile, 13 other senators -- from both sides of the aisle -- have signed on to a plan for universal coverage that includes a tax on employer-provided benefits. "I think it's extremely important from a credibility standpoint to show the American people that you're making savings in the enormous sums now being spent on health care before you go out and ask them for billions of dollars more," said Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.), one of the sponsors of that proposal. "And I don't think I'm the only senator who feels that way." So far, administration officials have been careful not to endorse the idea, which Obama blasted as a major tax increase last year after Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) made it the centerpiece of his presidential campaign's health plan. But the president hasn't slammed the door on it, either. This week, White House budget director Peter Orszag said taxing employer benefits was among several ideas that "most firmly should remain on the table." White House economic adviser Jason Furman called for an end to the so-called "employer exclusion" before he joined the administration. Meanwhile, some congressional Democrats say the White House has signaled that Obama would accept a tax on employer benefits as long as he didn't have to propose it himself. "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/11/AR2009031103827.html?hpid=moreheadlines"
quote: Barack Obama: You may end up getting a $5,000 tax credit. Here’s the only problem: Your employer now has to pay taxes on the health care that you’re getting from your employer. McCain’s plan doesn’t call for taxing employers on health care benefits; it would instead tax employees. As the law stands now, employees don’t pay taxes on the dollar value of their health insurance benefits. Under McCain’s plan, they would.

content: All through the election Obama attacked McCain on his health care proposal of taxing employer benefits. Now his administration is proposing the exact same thing. This is from an article dated October 4th, 2008: quote: The Obama campaign is opening up a major new offensive against McCain on health care that includes a forceful speech today denouncing McCain's plan as "radical," as well as a blitz of ads like this new one: The ad hammers McCain's proposed tax of health benefits as a "trillion dollar tax" and the "largest middle class tax hike ever," an effort to turn McCain's frequent claim that Obama would hike middle class taxes on its head. With the push on health care, which has been gearing up for some time now, the Obama team is homing in on a specific pocketbook issue in order to paint McCain as the risky, uncertain, and even frightening choice at a time when public fears are fixed squarely on the economy. Many Dems think that Obama's strongest suit amid all the generalized anxiety is to close out the race with as much specificity as possible as to how precisely he will improve people's lives, and why McCain would make them worse off. "http://tpmelectioncentral.talkingpointsmemo.com/2008/10/obama_ad_attacks_mccain_health.php"
quote: The Obama campaign is opening up a major new offensive against McCain on health care that includes a forceful speech today denouncing McCain's plan as "radical," as well as a blitz of ads like this new one: The ad hammers McCain's proposed tax of health benefits as a "trillion dollar tax" and the "largest middle class tax hike ever," an effort to turn McCain's frequent claim that Obama would hike middle class taxes on its head. With the push on health care, which has been gearing up for some time now, the Obama team is homing in on a specific pocketbook issue in order to paint McCain as the risky, uncertain, and even frightening choice at a time when public fears are fixed squarely on the economy. Many Dems think that Obama's strongest suit amid all the generalized anxiety is to close out the race with as much specificity as possible as to how precisely he will improve people's lives, and why McCain would make them worse off.

This is from an article dated October 4th, 2008:  "http://tpmelectioncentral.talkingpointsmemo.com/2008/10/obama_ad_attacks_mccain_health.php"
title: Worker's Health Benefits Eyed For Taxation

content: quote: Well, if you are wealthy enough to afford health insurance you must be rich. While I know you were being tongue-in-cheek, try telling that to military families and retirees ... TriCare would seem to fall into the category of health benefits received from an employer. This is a Pandora's Box that I would not want to see opened ... and whether Obama proposes it or not ... if he signs the bill, he owns it ... and defaults on his promise to 95% of working Americans.

content: This is from Barack Obama's website comparing the tax plans of Obama and McCain. quote: $3.6 Trillion in Tax Increases on Working Families. McCain’s health plan would require families to pay income taxes on their health benefits. According to McCain top advisors, his health care plan will accordingly be financed by a $3.6 trillion tax increase on working families. Even after taking into account McCain’s health tax credit, eventually tens of millions of middle class families would pay more taxes. "http://www.barackobama.com/pdf/taxes/Tax_Plan_Comparison_FINAL.pdf"
quote: $3.6 Trillion in Tax Increases on Working Families. McCain’s health plan would require families to pay income taxes on their health benefits. According to McCain top advisors, his health care plan will accordingly be financed by a $3.6 trillion tax increase on working families. Even after taking into account McCain’s health tax credit, eventually tens of millions of middle class families would pay more taxes.

content: Making an assumption that health costs are deuctible from income for tax purposes, are they? Stands to reason that if somebody else, like an employer is paying for them, that's a taxable benefit- just like the rest of salary and wages. The only folk that would hurt would be the abovw median income folk, and they might be able to afford their own health care. Co-payments and extraneous health care costs should be tax deductible.
reply: Making an assumption that health costs are deuctible from income for tax purposes, are they? content: quote: Originally posted by popsiq: Making an assumption that health costs are deuctible from income for tax purposes, are they? Stands to reason that if somebody else, like an employer is paying for them, that's a taxable benefit- just like the rest of salary and wages. The only folk that would hurt would be the abovw median income folk, and they might be able to afford their own health care. Co-payments and extraneous health care costs should be tax deductible. I used to get company paid health care benefits. Oddly enough I never regarded myself as "above medium income." It is an outrage to tax medical care at all. But when all is said and done, this is So Far just talk. Words like "hypocrite" are premature... Patience, patience... Dave

Dave quote: Meanwhile, some congressional Democrats say the White House has signaled that Obama would accept a tax on employer benefits as long as he didn't have to propose it himself. Unless "some congressional Democrats" are liars, THAT is hypocrisy ... don't care how you slice it or whether it comes to pass. It also replaces the "Here" in "The Buck Stops Here" with "There" ... You've got to find some irony in the fact that the shift is away from reducing some rich guy's tax exemptions towards taxing the little guy on what some on this board are fond of calling a "right".

Dave Well Dave ... we all know the NYT never tells a lie ... quote: Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc)

Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc)

So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc) Ahh, but I was referring to the earlier post which contained this gem: "White House economic adviser Jason Furman called for an end to the so-called "employer exclusion" before he joined the administration." From time to time I post what I think of the New York Times - And I say, (more or less) "It's the best of the Conservative Media." But if you note, I am quite clear in my feelings on this issue. All I am saying is that I'll believe it when I see it. This is not to say that it wont happen - But I'm not going to attack Mr. Bush for putting all Americans into concentration camps either... ****************** BTW - Here's a story that is completely off topic. I've been waiting for an opportunity to give you this information - No reply is necessary - Just food for thought. "http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7938001.stm" It relates to an earlier discussion on batteries... Dave

If and when this "proposal" becomes concrete I will not be shy about using the word "hypocrite." In fact, that will be the tamest of my remarks... Dave Well Dave ... we all know the NYT never tells a lie ... quote: Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc)

title: Worker's Health Benefits Eyed For Taxation

content: Does anyone remember this quote from the first Presidential Debate? quote: Barack Obama: You may end up getting a $5,000 tax credit. Here’s the only problem: Your employer now has to pay taxes on the health care that you’re getting from your employer. McCain’s plan doesn’t call for taxing employers on health care benefits; it would instead tax employees. As the law stands now, employees don’t pay taxes on the dollar value of their health insurance benefits. Under McCain’s plan, they would. This article was in the Washington Post today. quote: With President Obama's plan to tax the rich to pay for health care facing deep skepticism on Capitol Hill, key lawmakers are pressing a different way to raise money: taxing the health benefits workers receive from their employers. Since companies began offering group health insurance on a large scale during World War II, the value of that benefit has never been counted as income, reducing workers' taxable earnings by an average of $9,000 a year for family coverage. In recent weeks, however, Sen. Max Baucus (D-Mont.), chairman of the tax-writing Finance Committee, has repeatedly advocated changing tax laws to include employer benefits, arguing that it makes sense to fund the health-care changes by sucking cash out of the existing system. Meanwhile, 13 other senators -- from both sides of the aisle -- have signed on to a plan for universal coverage that includes a tax on employer-provided benefits. "I think it's extremely important from a credibility standpoint to show the American people that you're making savings in the enormous sums now being spent on health care before you go out and ask them for billions of dollars more," said Sen. Ron Wyden (D-Ore.), one of the sponsors of that proposal. "And I don't think I'm the only senator who feels that way." So far, administration officials have been careful not to endorse the idea, which Obama blasted as a major tax increase last year after Sen. John McCain (R-Ariz.) made it the centerpiece of his presidential campaign's health plan. But the president hasn't slammed the door on it, either. This week, White House budget director Peter Orszag said taxing employer benefits was among several ideas that "most firmly should remain on the table." White House economic adviser Jason Furman called for an end to the so-called "employer exclusion" before he joined the administration. Meanwhile, some congressional Democrats say the White House has signaled that Obama would accept a tax on employer benefits as long as he didn't have to propose it himself. "http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/03/11/AR2009031103827.html?hpid=moreheadlines"
quote: Barack Obama: You may end up getting a $5,000 tax credit. Here’s the only problem: Your employer now has to pay taxes on the health care that you’re getting from your employer. McCain’s plan doesn’t call for taxing employers on health care benefits; it would instead tax employees. As the law stands now, employees don’t pay taxes on the dollar value of their health insurance benefits. Under McCain’s plan, they would.

content: All through the election Obama attacked McCain on his health care proposal of taxing employer benefits. Now his administration is proposing the exact same thing. This is from an article dated October 4th, 2008: quote: The Obama campaign is opening up a major new offensive against McCain on health care that includes a forceful speech today denouncing McCain's plan as "radical," as well as a blitz of ads like this new one: The ad hammers McCain's proposed tax of health benefits as a "trillion dollar tax" and the "largest middle class tax hike ever," an effort to turn McCain's frequent claim that Obama would hike middle class taxes on its head. With the push on health care, which has been gearing up for some time now, the Obama team is homing in on a specific pocketbook issue in order to paint McCain as the risky, uncertain, and even frightening choice at a time when public fears are fixed squarely on the economy. Many Dems think that Obama's strongest suit amid all the generalized anxiety is to close out the race with as much specificity as possible as to how precisely he will improve people's lives, and why McCain would make them worse off. "http://tpmelectioncentral.talkingpointsmemo.com/2008/10/obama_ad_attacks_mccain_health.php"
quote: The Obama campaign is opening up a major new offensive against McCain on health care that includes a forceful speech today denouncing McCain's plan as "radical," as well as a blitz of ads like this new one: The ad hammers McCain's proposed tax of health benefits as a "trillion dollar tax" and the "largest middle class tax hike ever," an effort to turn McCain's frequent claim that Obama would hike middle class taxes on its head. With the push on health care, which has been gearing up for some time now, the Obama team is homing in on a specific pocketbook issue in order to paint McCain as the risky, uncertain, and even frightening choice at a time when public fears are fixed squarely on the economy. Many Dems think that Obama's strongest suit amid all the generalized anxiety is to close out the race with as much specificity as possible as to how precisely he will improve people's lives, and why McCain would make them worse off.

This is from an article dated October 4th, 2008:  "http://tpmelectioncentral.talkingpointsmemo.com/2008/10/obama_ad_attacks_mccain_health.php"

content: quote: Well, if you are wealthy enough to afford health insurance you must be rich. While I know you were being tongue-in-cheek, try telling that to military families and retirees ... TriCare would seem to fall into the category of health benefits received from an employer. This is a Pandora's Box that I would not want to see opened ... and whether Obama proposes it or not ... if he signs the bill, he owns it ... and defaults on his promise to 95% of working Americans.

content: This is from Barack Obama's website comparing the tax plans of Obama and McCain. quote: $3.6 Trillion in Tax Increases on Working Families. McCain’s health plan would require families to pay income taxes on their health benefits. According to McCain top advisors, his health care plan will accordingly be financed by a $3.6 trillion tax increase on working families. Even after taking into account McCain’s health tax credit, eventually tens of millions of middle class families would pay more taxes. "http://www.barackobama.com/pdf/taxes/Tax_Plan_Comparison_FINAL.pdf"
quote: $3.6 Trillion in Tax Increases on Working Families. McCain’s health plan would require families to pay income taxes on their health benefits. content: Making an assumption that health costs are deuctible from income for tax purposes, are they? Stands to reason that if somebody else, like an employer is paying for them, that's a taxable benefit- just like the rest of salary and wages. The only folk that would hurt would be the abovw median income folk, and they might be able to afford their own health care. Co-payments and extraneous health care costs should be tax deductible.

title: Worker's Health Benefits Eyed For Taxation

content: quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Unless "some congressional Democrats" are liars, THAT is hypocrisy ... don't care how you slice it or whether it comes to pass. It also replaces the "Here" in "The Buck Stops Here" with "There" ... I also read the article. But even after reading the article I can't name these "Congressional Democrats." The article also quotes an Obama staff member as saying this was a good idea, and then mentions that he said this BEFORE he became a staff member. If and when this "proposal" becomes concrete I will not be shy about using the word "hypocrite." In fact, that will be the tamest of my remarks... Dave Well Dave ... we all know the NYT never tells a lie ... quote: Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc)
quote: Originally posted by Grachus: quote: Originally posted by I_M_Qwerty: Unless "some congressional Democrats" are liars, THAT is hypocrisy ... don't care how you slice it or whether it comes to pass. It also replaces the "Here" in "The Buck Stops Here" with "There" ... I also read the article. But even after reading the article I can't name these "Congressional Democrats." The article also quotes an Obama staff member as saying this was a good idea, and then mentions that he said this BEFORE he became a staff member. If and when this "proposal" becomes concrete I will not be shy about using the word "hypocrite." In fact, that will be the tamest of my remarks... Dave
reply: Well Dave ... we all know the NYT never tells a lie ... quote: Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc)

If and when this "proposal" becomes concrete I will not be shy about using the word "hypocrite." In fact, that will be the tamest of my remarks... Dave Well Dave ... we all know the NYT never tells a lie ... quote: Now that Mr. Obama has begun the health debate, several advisers say that while he will not propose changing the tax-free status of employee health benefits, neither will he oppose it if Congress does so. At a recent Congressional hearing, Senator Ron Wyden, an Oregon Democrat whose own health plan would make benefits taxable, asked Peter R. Orszag, the president’s budget director, about the issue. Mr. Orszag replied that it “most firmly should remain on the table.” Mr. Orszag, an economist who has served as director of the Congressional Budget Office, has written favorably of taxing some employer-provided health benefits and using the revenue savings for other health-related incentives. So has another Obama adviser, Jason Furman, the deputy director of the White House National Economic Council. "http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/29703278" (NYT article by Calmes and Pear ... carried by msnbc) Ahh, but I was referring to the earlier post which contained this gem: "White House economic adviser Jason Furman called for an end to the so-called "employer exclusion" before he joined the administration." From time to time I post what I think of the New York Times - And I say, (more or less) "It's the best of the Conservative Media." But if you note, I am quite clear in my feelings on this issue. All I am saying is that I'll believe it when I see it. This is not to say that it wont happen - But I'm not going to attack Mr. Bush for putting all Americans into concentration camps either... ****************** BTW - Here's a story that is completely off topic. I've been waiting for an opportunity to give you this information - No reply is necessary - Just food for thought. "http://newsvote.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/7938001.stm" It relates to an earlier discussion on batteries... Dave
